msgSnippet: I completely avoid all of the cygwin CLASSPATH problem by using ant, having a CLASSPATH of . and then adding to it within my ant build file. Simon

I completely avoid all of the cygwin CLASSPATH problem by using ant, having=
 a CLASSPATH of "." and then adding to it within my ant build file.

Simon
=

>-----Original Message-----
>From: Ken Gentle [mailto:j.kenneth.gentle@acm=
.org]
>Sent: Wednesday, October 15, 2003 9:35 AM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com=

>Subject: Re: [junit] junit and cygwin
>
>
>At 10:15 2003-10-15, you wrote=
:
>>On Tue, 2003-10-14 at 16:59, Ken Gentle wrote:
>> > That's a very inter=
esting question -- JUnit is Java,
>> > write-once-run-anywhere, remember? ;=
^)
>> >
>> > You don't need a special distribution.  Just download 
>JUnit,=
 get your
>> > JDK/JRE visible from a cygwin shell prompt, and set it up 
>=
just like the
>> > instructions describe.
>>
>>Not exactly.  There are issu=
es with how Cygwin deals with the
>>classpath.  Cygwin does not pass along =
the classpath properly to your
>>Windows version JVM.  You need to do somet=
hing like this "java
>>-classpath `cygpath -wp $CLASSPATH` [arguments]" whi=
ch changes the
>>classpath into a Windows style path.  A quick google on "c=
ygwin java
>>classpath" would have turned up "http://www.inonit.com/cygwin/=
faq/",
>>probably as the first hit.
>
>Sorry, I was unclear -- I've been us=
ing cygwin for years and 
>tend forget to 
>mention the minor path magic re=
quired.  But it is really 
>minor, using cygpath.
>
>
>>=3Djason
>>
>>
